Dear Thomas Scheuer:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214. Compliance with the child protection
Section law.
Description (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law, 1975 PA
238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency was informed during parenting time that the children
are being maltreated in the foster home and the agency has not
reported this.
Investigation Interviews:
On 5/20/2025 I interviewed Parent C by telephone. Parent C
reported her two children, Child A and Child B are placed with the
agency, and she is concerned Foster Care Worker and agency
are not doing anything about the concerns brought up to the
agency about the children’s care and treatment. Parent C
reported the children are being mistreated in their foster home
placement. She reported the children had reported only being fed
once a day, at night, because they eat two meals at school.
Additionally, Child B wets her bed and she and Child A have
reported as punishment their windows are opened, and their
covers/sheets are taken. Parent C reported two weeks ago the
children came to their visit with their father, Parent D, and they
had colds. Parent C wondered if the colds were due to the
children’s windows being left open. Parent C further reported that
the foster parents talk negatively about the parents with the
children, and Child B is bullied at school, was pushed down, with
no one doing anything about it. Parent C reported these concerns
were mentioned to her by her husband, Parent D. Parent C
reported Parent D has visitation rights with both children as
opposed to her, but she sent an email to Foster Care Worker
(FCW) and Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) about these concerns.
Parent C said she sent her first email to FCW and FCS on
4/1/2025; and that email was about the children sharing with
Parent D that the foster parents were talking negatively about
them as parents. Parent C said neither FCW nor FCS responded
to her email. Parent C reported sending another email to FCW
and FCS on 4/8/2025; and she included Program Manager on that
email. She said she also tried to forward her 4/1/2025 email to
Program Manager but was unable to do so until later. Parent C
reported her 4/8/2025 email was about the children reporting they
were only being fed one meal a day due to eating two meals at
2

school, and the windows being opened to air out the room,
because Child B was having bed wetting accidents. Parent C said
Program Manager responded to her on 4/10/2025 that Program
Manager will look into the concerns. Parent C said she has not
heard anything further from Program Manager or the agency
about her and Parent D’s concerns about the children’s
mistreatment in foster care.
On 5/21/2025 I spoke with the Chief Administrator (CA) about
this complaint by telephone. CA reported when the children’s
parents brought up the concerns the agency immediately made a
children services referral. CA reported the agency investigated
the concerns. CA reported FCS and FCW would have more
details about this situation and that those staff can be contacted.
On 5/28/2025 I spoke with Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) about
the allegations via TEAMS. FCS reported FCW made a children
services referral about these concerns in April 2025. He reported
the agency was advised of the allegations on 4/30/2025 during
Parent D’s parenting time. He reported the information was
received directly by FCW who called him, and he advised her to
contact children services, which FCW did. FCS reported the
children are placed in a licensed foster home and to his
knowledge, licensing was initiating a special evaluation about the
allegations.
FCS reported Parent C was not visiting with the children, but
Parent D was, and initially Parent D was not engaging with staff.
He reported Parent C’s rights are terminated to all the children
except Child B. He reported discussing all things with Parent C
was not appropriate in the past due to her parental rights being
terminated, but it is now appropriate to discuss Child B with Parent
C. He denied Parent C emailing him on 4/1/2025. He said Parent
C emailed him on 4/22/2025, and 5/1/2025 but neither of those
emails were about these allegations. He reported Parent C also
emailed him on 5/8/2025, and that email was about these
concerns; and he responded and suggested Parent C to call him
and FCW. He said he set up a TEAMs meeting which was held on
5/20/2025. FCS reported at the 5/20/2025 meeting the agency
shared with Parent C that since her rights were terminated to all
the children except Child B, they could not discuss the other
children, but they discussed action plans taken related to Child B.
FCS reiterated a children service referral was in fact submitted
related to the allegations prior to 5/1/2025. He emailed me a copy
of the DHS-3200(Report of Actual or Suspected Child Abuse or
Neglect) and emails received from Parent C.
3

On 5/30/2025 I spoke with Program Manager (PM) related to the
allegations by telephone. PM reported the allegations came to the
agency’s attention prior to any email from Parent C and the
agency completed a children services referral. She reported
Parent C has been emailing her every other day; and she has
replied to Parent C; as did FCS. She denied receiving an email
from Parent C on 4/1/2025 or 4/8/2025. She said Parent C
emailed her on 5/8/2025, stating the children are sick, the foster
parent speak negatively about her and Parent D, Child A and
Child B have colds and do not have enough covers for their beds,
and the children get two meals at school and only one in the foster
home. PM said she replied to Parent C’s 5/8/2025 email on
5/9/2025. PM said Parent C sent another email just to her on
5/11/2025, which she forwarded to FCS and FCW because Parent
C reported sending them to FCS and FCW, and them not
responding to it. PM said Parent C had advised there was an
attachment in the email, but none was there; and PM advised
Parent C of that. PM reported the agency was following up on any
relatives Parent C provided; and the special evaluation on the
foster parents about the allegations is ongoing. PM reported the
special evaluation was opened on 4/30/2025; and she became
aware of it on 5/1/2025. She said a home visit was made by FCW
and two other workers related to the allegations.
On 6/3/2025, I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) by
telephone related to the allegations. FCW affirmed information as
reported by FCS and PM. FCW reported assignment to Child A’s
and Child B’s case since August 2024. She reported an
awareness of bedwetting for Child B; because the foster parent
had reported Child B wets the bed one to three times per night.
FCW reported both Child B and the foster parents have denied
Parent C’s allegation that sheets are taken from Child B at night
when Child B wets herself. FCW reported the aforementioned was
an allegation that came after parenting time on 5/8/2025, as the
child said goodbye to Parent D. FCW reported she followed up on
that allegation at a home visit on 5/9/2025 where it was denied.
She also spoke with the children and foster parents about the
meals allegations. The children all reported getting three meals a
day during the week, which was that two of them are at school.
They reported during the weekend, they also get three meals a
day, unless they sleep in, which they often do on Saturday; and
when they do sleep in they get two meals. However, if they are
hungry and ask for food it is available to them and provided.
Snacks are also available to the children, if they ask, and FCW
4

reported she had advised the children to ask when they want
something because the children were not doing that.
Document Review:
Child A’s and Child B’s MISACWIS records which showed:
• Both children are temporary court wards as of 8/2/2024 and
3/20/2025 respectively.
• They have five other older siblings in care.
• They were placed in their current foster home placement
with Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 on 11/13/2024
and 3/20/2025 respectively.
Copies of emails from FCS that contained copies of:
• A DHS-3200 dated 4/30/2025 which indicated Foster
Parent 1 threatened to beat Child A with a belt if Child A hit
the other foster child again; and that the foster parent
denied using physical discipline in the past. Additionally,
Foster Parent 1 made the other foster child to sleep on the
floor due to the boys talking during bedtime.
• An 4/22/2025 email from Parent C that appeared to
complain to FCS about FCW; indicating FCW does not
understand her; started out on the wrong foot with her
when FCW first got the case.
• A 5/1/2025 email from Parent C to FCS, FCW, and Parent
D where Parent C indicated she would not have paid
strangers speaking negatively about her and Parent D. If
this matter is not addressed right away, she will start
making complaints to people about the recipients’ pay
grade; and if the recipients retaliate it will be reported.
• A 5/8/2025 email from Parent C to FCS, FCW and PM
where Parent C indicated the children being sick, allegedly
due to the windows being left open and sheets taken as
punishment, as well as Child B having accidents; Child B
being bullied at school, pushed down; and the children not
eating enough, due to only getting one meal in the foster
home because they eat breakfast and lunch at school; and
that the foster parents are speaking negatively about them
as birth parents. Parent C indicated in this email she was
giving the agency a fair warning about the safety of the
children; that these things should be addressed in court.
Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s CWLM record which
showed two special evaluations:
• Special evaluation 2025SEC0000587 dated 6/13/2025. The
complaint was initiated on 5/1/2025 for allegations of
physical discipline of the children; and making a child sleep
5

on the floor. The investigation concluded with no evidence
that the foster parents used or threatened to use physical
discipline with Child A, Child B or the other child in the
home or an inappropriate action by the foster parents. All
three children denied such actions occurring and reported
feeling safe in the home, having enough food and enough
clothing.
• Special evaluation 2025SEC0000738 dated 7/8/2025. The
complaint was initiated on 6/8/2025. The complaint related
to allegations that these foster parents were not ensuring
for services for the children and are speaking negatively to
the foster children about their birth parents. No rule
violations were substantiated related to these allegations.
• These special evaluations addressed some concerns noted
by Parent C, related to maltreatment; and FCW addressed
some concerns during a home visit with the foster parents
and children on 5/8/2025 and 5/9/2025.
Analysis The evidence does not support a lack of failure to report. It
showed the agency made a referral to children services related to
allegations of possible maltreatment in the foster home and the
agency initiated a special evaluation on the foster home.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code & R400.12327 Special evaluation.
Section (1) Upon receipt of any information that is related to a
Description possible noncompliance with any foster home rule, the
agency must do all of the following:
(b) Initiate Special evaluation of the foster home as soon as is
indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
Violation Additional Finding.
Type
Allegation All of the allegations that were alleged by the birth parent were not
investigated in the agency’s special evaluation.
Investigation Interviews:
I interviewed Chief Administrator, Foster Supervisor, Program
Manager about the allegation on 5/21/2025, 5/28/2025 and
5/30/2025 respectively either by telephone or TEAMs. All
reported concerns and allegations expressed by Parent C were
addressed by the agency. They reported a children services
referral was completed and a special evaluation was completed
on the foster home.
On 6/3/2025, I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) by
telephone related to the allegations. As reported earlier, FCW

foster parents had reported it occurring one to three times per

denied Parent C’s allegation that sheets are taken from Child B at
night when Child B wets herself. FCW reported the
aforementioned was an allegation that came after parenting time
on 5/8/2025, as the child said goodbye to Parent D. FCW reported
she followed up on that allegation at a home visit on 5/9/2025
where it was denied. She also spoke with the children and foster

hungry and ask for food it is available to them and provided.
Snacks are also available to the children, if they ask, and FCW
reported she had advised the children to ask when they want
something because the children were not doing that.
Documents Reviewed:
Child A’s and Child B’s MISACWIS records which showed:
• They were placed in their current foster home placement
with Foster Parent 1 on 11/13/2024 and 3/20/2025
respectively.
• A 5/8/2025 and 5/9/2025 social work contact of a foster
home visit by FCW at 4:00pm and 5:38 PM respectively
that indicated:
➢ On 5/8/2025 FCW completed a foster home visit
and spoke privately with Child A and the foster
parents related to allegations that included
verbalized threats and concerns regarding bedding
arrangements. At this home visit, a safety plan was
developed with the foster parents around Child A
and Child B sleeping in their own beds every night
and the foster parents refraining from physical
discipline and following the agency’s behavior
management policy.
➢ On 5/9/2025 FCW completed a foster home visit
and spoke with Child B and the foster parents about
concerns regarding a recent complaint. Child B
reported she has always slept in her bed and was
never made to sleep outside of her room or on the
floor. FCW viewed Child B’s bed, which had
appropriately fitted sheets, bedding, and a mattress
7

protector. Child A stated that she gets cold at night;
and FCW viewed a blanket on the bed and asked
Child B whether she ever asked for additional
bedding if she is cold, and Child B stated no. FCW
asked Child B about food intake and Child B
reported usually eating one, two and sometimes
three times a day. That “I eat good". Child B
reported not getting a snack, but also that she does
not ask for one.
➢ Additionally at the home visit on 5/9/2025 FCW
asked Child B about school and Child B reported
that someone pushed her at school during recess,
because she didn't see them. Child B was observed
to have a small bruise on her right shoulder, which
Child B stated was from falling. Child B reported
telling her teacher about the incident. Furthermore,
when FCW spoke privately with the foster parents
she informed them Child B stated that she gets
cold; and the foster parents stated that Child B has
not asked for additional bedding. FCW also spoke
with the foster parent about food, and allowing Child
B to have snacks when requested. FCW informed
the foster parents that they spoke with Child B
about using her words. The foster parents reported
that Child B continues to wet the bed at night.
Copies of emails from FCS that contained copies of:
• A DHS-3200 dated 4/30/2025 which indicated Foster
Parent 1 threatened to beat Child A with a belt if Child A hit
the other foster child again; and that the foster parent
denied using was physically disciplined in the past.
Additionally, Foster Parent 1 made the other foster child to
sleep on the floor due to the boys talking during bed time.
• A 5/1/2025 email from Parent C to FCS, FCW, and Parent
D where Parent C indicated she would not have paid
strangers speaking negatively about her and Parent D. If
this matter is not addressed right away, she will start
making complaints to people about the recipients’ pay
grade; and if the recipients retaliate it will be reported.
• A 5/8/2025 email from Parent C to FCS, FCW and PM
where Parent C indicated the children being sick, allegedly
due to the windows being left open and sheets taken as
punishment, as well as Child B having accident; her being
bullied at school, pushed down; and the children not eating
enough, due to only getting one meal in the foster home
because they eat breakfast and lunch at school; and that

the foster parents are speaking negatively about them as
birth parents. Parent C indicated in this email she was
giving the agency a fair warning about the safety of the
children; that these things should be addressed in court
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2’s CWLM record which
showed two special evaluations:
• Special evaluation 2025SEC0000587 dated 6/13/2025. The
complaint was initiated on 5/1/2025 for allegations of
physical discipline of the children; and making a child sleep
on the floor. The investigation concluded with no evidence
that the foster parents used or threatened to use physical
discipline with Child A, Child B or the other child in the
home or an inappropriate action by the foster parents. All
three children denied such actions occurring and reported
reports feeling safe in the home, having enough food and
enough clothing.
• Special evaluation 2025SEC0000738 dated 7/8/2025. The
complaint was initiated on 6/8/2025. The complaint related
to allegations that these foster parents were not ensuring
for services for the children and are speaking negatively to
the foster children about their birth parents. No rule
violations were substantiated related to these allegations.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed, the evidence
showed FCW addressed some concerns/allegations reported by
Parent C during foster home visits on 5/8/2025 and 5/9/2025.
Those concerns/allegations also related to foster home rules
violations, and a special evaluation did not address allegations
related to adequate number of meals, or sheets being withheld
due to the child’s bedwetting.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
